page.paragraph: Now listen to two students as they discuss the note.
Hey, Matt, did you see the note on the classroom door?
Which note? Which classroom door?
I guess you didn't see it, huh?
No, I don't know what you're talking about. There's a note on a door?
Yeah, there's a note on Professor Allen's classroom door. He's sick, and he won't be here for the rest of the week.
I'm sorry he's sick, but at least we'll get a little break while he's gone.
I wish we were getting a break, but…well, we're not.
What do you mean? If Professor Allen's not here, then we'll get a break from class, won't we?
We'll get a break from class, but we won't get a break from work. The note gives us instructions to do some work, a lot of work, while the professor's gone.
What are we supposed to do?
We have three chapters to read.
Three chapters? That's a lot.
Oh, but that's not all.
What else is there?
We have to write one essay for each of the three chapters.
We have to write three essays?
Yes, and have them ready to turn in on Monday.
That's a lot of work.
It is, but that's still not quite all.
It's not?
No, we also have to be prepared for a quiz on Monday.
A quiz, too? We're not getting any kind of break at all. In fact, this is a lot more work than we'd have if the professor weren't sick.
